dc:description: *B3GALT6* was first reported in relation to autosomal recessive congenital disorder of glycosylation in 2013 (Nakajima et al., PMID: 23664117). Per criteria outlined by the ClinGen Lumping and Splitting Working Group, we found no difference in molecular mechanism, inheritance pattern, or phenotypic variability. Therefore, the following disease entities have been lumped into one disease entity, Al-Gazali syndrome (OMIM:609465), Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, spondylodysplastic type, 2 (OMIM:615349), and Spondyloepimetaphyseal dysplasia with joint laxity, type 1, with or without fractures (OMIM:271640) and curated under the disease entity congenital disorder of glycosylation. 22 unique variants (start loss, missense, in-frame indel, and frameshift) that have been reported in 17 probands in 7 publications (PMIDs: 23664117, 25149931, 28649518, 23664118, 29230159, 34529350, 29443383) are included in this curation. More evidence is available in the literature, but the maximum score for genetic evidence (12 pts.) has been reached. Of note, two reports of monogenic (autosomal dominant) inheritance have been published in the literature, but there is not enough evidence to rule out a second variant in trans (PMIDs: 23664117, 35734427). The mechanism of pathogenicity is known to be loss of function. This gene-disease relationship is also supported by an animal model (PMID: 33363150). In summary, there is definitive evidence supporting the relationship between *B3GALT6* and autosomal recessive congenital disorder of glycosylation. This has been repeatedly demonstrated in both the research and clinical diagnostic settings and has been upheld over time. This classification was approved by the ClinGen Congenital Disorders of Glycosylaton GCEP on the meeting date January 15, 2025 (SOP Version 11).

evidence.dc:description: Zebrafish exhibited craniofacial dysmorphism, generalized skeletal dysplasia, skin involvement and indications for muscle hypotonia.
evidence.rdfs:label: Delbaere Zebrafish

evidence.dc:description: Functional data for this variant already scored on a different proband.
Decreased rate of GAG synthesis and impaired HS synthesis (fig 4).
Single-exon gene and not expected to undergo NMD.
Functional data for this variant already scored on a different proband.

Mutant and wt B3GALT6 protein was expressed in HeLa cells. Mutant protein had a molecular weight ∼4 kD lower compared with the wild-type (WT) protein (Figure 2A). This suggests that translation initiation at the second ATG of the coding sequence, at position c.124, would become the initiation codon because of the mutation, probably resulting in an N-terminal deletion of 41 amino acids (p.Met1_Ala41del). Authors checked the subcellular localization of the mutant B3GALT6 protein by immunocytochemistry. WT-B3GALT6 was observed in a perinuclear region overlapping with that for α-mannosidase II, a Golgi marker. The mutant B3GALT6 protein was observed in the nucleus and cytoplasm (Figure 2B).

Fig S1 shows mislocalization by IHC
Fig 2C shows decreased GalT-II function
